review.title: Analogy-Based and Case-Based Reasoning: Two sides of the same coin
review.abstract: Analogy-Based (or Analogical) and Case-Based Reasoning (ABR and CBR) are two similar problem solving processes based on the adaptation of the solution of past problems for use with a new analogous problem. In this paper we review these two processes and we give some real world examples with emphasis to the field of Medicine, where one can find some of the most common and useful CBR applications. We also underline the differences between CBR and the classical rule-induction algorithms, we discuss the criticism for CBR methods and we focus on the future trends of research in the area of CBR.

metadata.title: Analogy-Based and Case-Based Reasoning: Two sides of the same coin

sections.heading: 2.3 Classroom experiments
sections.text: A series of experiments (e.g. [31], [36], [80], etc.) has clearly demonstrated that if the source and the target problems share both superficial and structural characteristics, a spontaneous positive transfer should be expected regardless of expertise. Indeed, although the subjects in these experiments were most likely beginners, it seems reasonable to conclude that if they showed positive transfer under these favorable conditions, experts should also be more likely to have spontaneous positive transfer than beginners. In contrast, if the source is a structural but not superficial problem (in this case the source is called Holyoaks terminology, a remote analogy of the target problem), spontaneous positive transfer should be more likely in experts than in beginners, if the source is a distracting problem, the spontaneous negative transfer should be stronger for beginners than for experts. Novick [62] supports her assertions that the results of the three experiments were ordered by the students.

sections.heading: 3.2 History of CBR
sections.text: The first traces of the CBR field come from the study of analogous thought processes (see section 2) and - further back - from the theories of conceptualization, problem solving and learning within philosophy and psychology (e.g. [102], [123], etc.). Thus, for example, it is better to be defined by their sets of instances or cases that concepts that are part of the psychological world, such as bird, tree, chair, car, etc., are the question of what kind of memory contexts are used for observed cognitive behaviors. A leading theory was the semantic memory model. Psychologists paid much attention to this theory ([42], [82], etc., as if researchers had artificial intelligence (AI) who have tried to create computer programs that model cognitive processes that modeled cognitive processes.

sections.heading: 3.5 Tools and applications of CBR
sections.text: A good tool should support a variety of retrieval mechanisms and allow them when they need it. In addition, the tool should be able to deal with large case numbers that increase the number of linear (at worst) cases. CBR first appeared in commercial tools in the early 1990s and was then sued to create numerous applications across a wide range of domains. Organisations such as IBM, VISA International, British Airways and NASA have already utilised CBR in applications such as customer service, aircraft maintenance, decision support and many other applications.

sections.heading: 4. Applications of CBR in Medical Domain
sections.text: In recent years, the number of cases where the disease has been diagnosed has multiplied, and in the next two years we will reduce the number of cases where the disease is diagnosed to a minimum.

sections.heading: 4.2 CBR-based system for diagnosis of heart diseases
sections.text: Heart disease is a vital health problem affecting millions of people. Heart disease occurs in 25 different cases; e.g. left-sided congestive heart failure, right-sided congestive heart failure, angina pectoris, myocardial infraction, and essential hypertension. The system is able to provide an appropriate diagnosis for the symptoms, symptoms, and examinations presented in a heart patient with the appropriate certainty factor. It can be used as a physician's assistant and supports training for junior doctors. In this system, knowledge is presented in the form of frames, and case memory contains 110 cases for 4 heart diseases, namely: mitral stenosis, left-sumvionment cancer institute User Interface QueringCase Symptoms Laboratory Tests AnalysisQuering Inference Diagnostic caseCBR ModelComputational Module Rule-based InferenceCase LibraryCase Retrieval Demosimilarcheslarity Case User ModuleBR Statistics Interface.

sections.heading: 4.3 Knowledge Engineering Issues in Developing Biomedical CBR Systems
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules they have set themselves.

sections.heading: 4.4 Benefits of the Expert Support Systems to Healthcare
sections.text: The advantages of the expert support systems approach in the healthcare sector are mainly related to the treatment of the patient. We can list several areas where expert systems bring advantages, namely: a) treatment selection - can be simplified by applying the if-then rules of an expert system; according to these rules, a doctor can conclude symptom and / or disease-appropriate treatment; b) diagnostic support - this comes from both rule-based and case-based systems. If-then rules allow the coding of knowledge linking symptoms to diseases, while case-based reasoning allows the disease to be found by comparing the patient's symptoms with those in a case-based knowledge base; c) analysis of treatment options - rules-based knowledge allows for so-called what-if analysis: What is likely if we apply a particular treatment? d) Maintaining medical history - is simple with case-based expert systems, whereby the cases of individual patients can be stored for both statistical purposes and case-based considerations.

sections.heading: 4.5 Conclusions
sections.text: CBR is a suitable method for all medical fields and tasks for the following reasons: cognitive appropriateness, explicit experience, duality of objective and subjective knowledge, automatic acquisition of subjective Voskoglou & Salem knowledge, and system integration. CBR presents an essential technology for building intelligent CBR systems for medical diagnoses that can significantly improve physicians "decision-making, helping physicians and physicians to review, analyze, and repair their solutions. A physician enters a description of the domain situation and his or her solution, and the system can recall cases with similar solutions and present their results to the student.

sections.heading: 5. Development trends of CBR methods and applications
sections.text: This year, it will be able to put itself at the top of the group.

sections.heading: 6. Final conclusions and discussion
sections.text: It is time for us to set out in search of new ways to travel the world.

Novick [62] claims further that, when the target and the source problem share structural, but not surface features (in this case the source, according to Holyoak’s [35] terminology, is called a remote analogue of the target problem), spontaneous positive transfer should be more likely in experts than in novices.

Novick [62] claims further that, when the target and the source problem share structural, but not surface features (in this case the source, according to Holyoak’s [35] terminology, is called a remote analogue of the target problem), spontaneous positive transfer should be more likely in experts than in novices.
Novick [62] supports her claims by the results of three experiments, where the subjects were undergraduate students of the Universities of Stanford and Los Angeles.

In [113] we have also performed four classroom experiments with subjects undergraduate students of the School of Management and Economics of the Technological Educational Institute of Messolonghi, Greece.

Schank [90] proposed a conceptual memory that combined semantic memory with Tulvin’s episodic memory.
Scripts [91] were proposed as a knowledge structure for the conceptual memory.
The acquisition of scripts, which are analogous to Minsky’s [59] frames, is the result of repeated exposure to a given situation.

Schank [92-93] postulated a more general structure to account for the diverse and heterogeneous nature of episodic memory, called memory organization packet (MOP).

Other early significant contributions to CBR include, the Memory-Based Reasoning (MBR) model of Stanfill and Waltz [104], designed for parallel computation rather than knowledge-based matching, the study of Phyllis Koton at MIT on the use of CBR to optimize performance in an existing knowledge based system resulted in the CASEY system [49], etc.

Among the earliest results was the work of Althoff , Richter and others at the University of Kaiserslautern for complex technical diagnosis within the MOLTKE system [8], which lead to the PATDEX system [75], and later to several other systems and methods.

At the University of Trondheim Aamodt and colleagues at Sintef studied the learning aspect of CBR in the context of knowledge acquisition and maintenance, while for PS the combined use of cases and general domain knowledge was focused [1] This lead to the development of CREEK system and to continued work on knowledge-intensive CBR.

On the cognitive science side significant work was done on analogical reasoning at Trinity College, Dublin [38] and by Strube’s group at the University of Freiburg, where the role of episodic knowledge in cognitive models was investigated in the EVENTS project [107].

The basic ideas and the underlined theories of CBR have spread quickly to other continents as well; from Japan, India [111] and other Asian countries, there are also activity points.
In Japan the interest is mainly focused towards the parallel computation approach in CBR [43].

Such a task-method decomposition of the four main steps of the CBR process to sub-steps, where related problem-solving methods are also described, is given – in the form of a decision tree - in Aamodt & Plaza ( [3]; Figure 2).
The methods shown in Aamodt’s and Plaza’s scheme [3], which are task decomposition and control methods, are actually high level method classes, from which one or more methods should be chosen.

A spherical observation of the task-oriented view of CBR described above, as Aamodt and Plaza [3] themselves accept, makes evident that their framework and analysis approach is strongly influenced by knowledge level modeling methods in general and by the Components of Expertise methodology in particular [105-106].

Salem in his plenary lecture [88] at the 16 WSEAS International Conference on Computers (Kos island, Greece, July 14-17, 2012) gives a graphical representation of the CBR methodology: When a new problem is introduced in the system, the problem is indexed, and subsequently, the indexes are used to retrieve past cases from memory.

Another example of integrating rules and cases is the BOLERO system [53], which has a meta-level architecture, where the base-level is composed of rules embodying knowledge to diagnose the plausible pneumonias of a patient, while the meta-level is a casebased planner that, at every moment is able to dictate which diagnoses are worthwhile to consider.

The main role of the general knowledge is to provide explanatory support to the case-based processes [2]; rules or deep models may also be used to solve problems on their own, if the case-based method fails.
This line of work has also being developed in Europe by systems like the Massive Memory Architecture and INRECA [55].
The problem domain is optimization of autoclave loading for heat treatment of composite materials [33].

A second fielded CBR system has been developed at General Dynamics, Electric Boat Division [15] handling the problem of the selection of the most appropriate mechanical equipment during the construction of ships, and to fit it to its use.

Knowledge engineering (KE) was defined in 1983 by Feigenbaum and McCorduck [20] as follows: KE is an engineering discipline that involves integrating knowledge into computer systems in order to solve complex problems normally requiring a high level of human expertise It follows a brief discussion of the knowledge engineering issues which are crucial in developing CBR Systems for any healthcare task [4-5].

The idea of CBR is becoming popular in developing knowledge-based systems because it automates applications that are based on precedent or that contain incomplete causal models [87].

metadata.abstractText: Analogy-Based (or Analogical) and Case-Based Reasoning (ABR and CBR) are two similar problem solving processes based on the adaptation of the solution of past problems for use with a new analogous problem. In this paper we review these two processes and we give some real world examples with emphasis to the field of Medicine, where one can find some of the most common and useful CBR applications. We also underline the differences between CBR and the classical rule-induction algorithms, we discuss the criticism for CBR methods and we focus on the future trends of research in the area of CBR.
